title: I'm named as an Heir to a Trust and want to sell my share of the Trust
question: I have a copy of the Trust what if anything do I need to look for in the Trust Document that would not allow me to sell my protion. You know any type of special legal wording that would stop me from selling my share.
answers:
Most trusts have a "spendthrift" provision which prohibits using any future distribution from the trust as collateral; once you receive a distribution, you can do what you want with it, but until you receive the distribution, you cannot count on it or use it for financial gain.

Also the administration of the trust may take a few months and until the Trustee is ready to make distribution, you won't know exactly how much you are going to receive. Remember that costs of administration and debts are paid before the beneficiaries.

DISCLAIMER: The information provided here is general information and your situation may differ. You should consult with an attorney with your specific documentation and information to get a true evaluation and options open to you. Trusts that restrict pledging, hypothecating, or selling your interest will have a clause commonly known as a "spendthrift" provision. Here is an example:

"The interests of the beneficiaries under this instrument are not transferable by voluntary or involuntary assignment or by operation of law, and shall be free from the claims of creditors and from attachment, execution, bankruptcy, and other legal process, to the maximum extent permitted by law."

I suggest you have a trust attorney review the document for restrictions.

This is a complex legal issue and you should get with a local attorney and have them review the trust agreement for you. In many instances, a trust interest cannot be sold because a certain portion of the distributions are discretionary (i.e. for health, education, maintenance and support). Further, if you do attempt to sell your interest, you will likely find the offers are substantially discounted from what you expect will be the value of the trust. This discounting is primarily due to the fact that the purchaser of your interest will have limited control over the liquidation or distribution of trust assets.
